trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Storage in five minutes | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Storage in five minutes | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Quickly ramp up on Microsoft Azure Blobs, Table, and Queues using Azure QuickStarts, Visual Studio, and the Azure Storage emulator. Run your first Azure Storage application in five minutes.
trans-unit.target: Quickly ramp up on Microsoft Azure Blobs, Table, and Queues using Azure QuickStarts, Visual Studio, and the Azure Storage emulator. Run your first Azure Storage application in five minutes.

trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Storage in five minutes
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Storage in five minutes

trans-unit.source: It's easy to get started developing against Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: It's easy to get started developing against Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to get an Azure Storage application up and running quickly.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to get an Azure Storage application up and running quickly.

trans-unit.source: We'll demonstrate two scenarios for easily ramping up on Azure Storage:
trans-unit.target: We'll demonstrate two scenarios for easily ramping up on Azure Storage:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Run your first Azure Storage application locally against the Azure Storage Emulator</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Run your first Azure Storage application locally against the Azure Storage Emulator</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Run your first Azure Storage application against Azure Storage in the cloud</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Run your first Azure Storage application against Azure Storage in the cloud</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: If you want to learn more about Azure Storage before diving into the code, see <link><linkText>Next Steps</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to learn more about Azure Storage before diving into the code, see <link><linkText>Next Steps</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have the following prerequisites before you start:
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have the following prerequisites before you start:

trans-unit.source: To compile and build the application, you'll need a version of <link><linkText>Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link> installed on your computer.
trans-unit.target: To compile and build the application, you'll need a version of <link><linkText>Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link> installed on your computer.

trans-unit.source: Install the latest version <link><linkText>Azure SDK for .NET</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Install the latest version <link><linkText>Azure SDK for .NET</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The SDK includes the Azure QuickStart sample projects, the Azure storage emulator, and the <link><linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for .NET</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The SDK includes the Azure QuickStart sample projects, the Azure storage emulator, and the <link><linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for .NET</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that you have <link><linkText>.NET Framework 4.5</linkText><title></title></link> installed on your computer, as it is required by the Azure QuickStart sample projects that we'll be using in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that you have <link><linkText>.NET Framework 4.5</linkText><title></title></link> installed on your computer, as it is required by the Azure QuickStart sample projects that we'll be using in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: If you are not sure which version of .NET Framework is installed in your computer, see <link><linkText>How to: Determine Which .NET Framework Versions Are Installed</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you are not sure which version of .NET Framework is installed in your computer, see <link><linkText>How to: Determine Which .NET Framework Versions Are Installed</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Or, press the Start button or the Windows key, type Control Panel.
trans-unit.target: Or, press the Start button or the Windows key, type Control Panel.

trans-unit.source: Then, click Programs > Programs and Features, and determine whether the .NET Framework 4.5 is listed among the installed programs.
trans-unit.target: Then, click Programs > Programs and Features, and determine whether the .NET Framework 4.5 is listed among the installed programs.

trans-unit.source: The latest version of the Azure Storage Client Library binaries is available on <link><linkText>NuGet</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The latest version of the Azure Storage Client Library binaries is available on <link><linkText>NuGet</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Run your first Azure Storage application locally against the Azure Storage Emulator
trans-unit.target: Run your first Azure Storage application locally against the Azure Storage Emulator

trans-unit.source: When developing an application that uses Azure Storage, you can run against the <link><linkText>Azure Storage Emulator</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: When developing an application that uses Azure Storage, you can run against the <link><linkText>Azure Storage Emulator</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The storage emulator provides a local environment that emulates the Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services for development purposes.
trans-unit.target: The storage emulator provides a local environment that emulates the Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services for development purposes.

trans-unit.source: You can use the storage emulator to test your storage application locally, without creating an Azure subscription or storage account, and without incurring any cost.
trans-unit.target: You can use the storage emulator to test your storage application locally, without creating an Azure subscription or storage account, and without incurring any cost.

trans-unit.source: To try it, let’s create a simple Azure Storage application using one of the Azure QuickStarts sample projects in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: To try it, let’s create a simple Azure Storage application using one of the Azure QuickStarts sample projects in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial focuses on the Azure Blob Storage, Azure Table Storage, and Azure Queue Storage sample projects:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial focuses on the Azure Blob Storage, Azure Table Storage, and Azure Queue Storage sample projects:

trans-unit.source: Start Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Start Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: From the File menu, click New Project.
trans-unit.target: From the File menu, click New Project.

trans-unit.source: In the New Project dialog box, click Installed > Templates > Visual C# > Cloud > Quick Starts > Data Services.
trans-unit.target: In the New Project dialog box, click Installed > Templates > Visual C# > Cloud > Quick Starts > Data Services.

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Choose one of the following templates: Azure Blob Storage, Azure Table Storage, or Azure Storage Queues.
trans-unit.target: Choose one of the following templates: Azure Blob Storage, Azure Table Storage, or Azure Storage Queues.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that .NET Framework 4.5 is selected as the target framework.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that .NET Framework 4.5 is selected as the target framework.

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: Specify a name for your project and create the new Visual Studio solution, as shown:
trans-unit.target: Specify a name for your project and create the new Visual Studio solution, as shown:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure QuickStarts</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure QuickStarts</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You may want to review the source code before running the application.
trans-unit.target: You may want to review the source code before running the application.

trans-unit.source: To review the code, select Solution Explorer on the View menu in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: To review the code, select Solution Explorer on the View menu in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Then, double click the Program.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Then, double click the Program.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Next, run the sample application in the Azure Storage Emulator:
trans-unit.target: Next, run the sample application in the Azure Storage Emulator:

trans-unit.source: Press the Start button or the Windows key, search for Azure Storage emulator, and start the application.
trans-unit.target: Press the Start button or the Windows key, search for Azure Storage emulator, and start the application.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, click Build Solution on the Build menu.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, click Build Solution on the Build menu.

trans-unit.source: On the Debug menu, Press F11 to run the solution step by step, or press F5 to run the solution from start to finish.
trans-unit.target: On the Debug menu, Press F11 to run the solution step by step, or press F5 to run the solution from start to finish.

trans-unit.source: Run your first Azure Storage application against Azure Storage in the cloud
trans-unit.target: Run your first Azure Storage application against Azure Storage in the cloud

trans-unit.source: To run against Azure Storage in the cloud, you'll need an Azure subscription and a storage account, if you don't have one already:
trans-unit.target: To run against Azure Storage in the cloud, you'll need an Azure subscription and a storage account, if you don't have one already:

trans-unit.source: To get an Azure subscription, see <link><linkText>Free Trial</linkText><title></title></link>, <link><linkText>Purchase Options</linkText><title></title></link>, and <link><linkText>Member Offers</linkText><title></title></link> (for members of MSDN, Microsoft Partner Network, and BizSpark, and other Microsoft programs).
trans-unit.target: To get an Azure subscription, see <link><linkText>Free Trial</linkText><title></title></link>, <link><linkText>Purchase Options</linkText><title></title></link>, and <link><linkText>Member Offers</linkText><title></title></link> (for members of MSDN, Microsoft Partner Network, and BizSpark, and other Microsoft programs).

trans-unit.source: To create a storage account in Azure, see <link><linkText>How to create, manage, or delete a storage account</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To create a storage account in Azure, see <link><linkText>How to create, manage, or delete a storage account</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Once you have an account, you can create a simple Azure Storage application using one of the Azure QuickStarts sample projects in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Once you have an account, you can create a simple Azure Storage application using one of the Azure QuickStarts sample projects in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial focuses on Azure Blob Storage, Azure Table Storage, and Azure Queue Storage sample projects:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial focuses on Azure Blob Storage, Azure Table Storage, and Azure Queue Storage sample projects:

trans-unit.source: Start Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Start Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: From the File menu, click New Project.
trans-unit.target: From the File menu, click New Project.

trans-unit.source: In the New Project dialog box, click Installed > Templates > Visual C# > Cloud > Quick Starts > Data Services.
trans-unit.target: In the New Project dialog box, click Installed > Templates > Visual C# > Cloud > Quick Starts > Data Services.

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Choose one of the following templates: Azure Blob Storage, Azure Table Storage, or Azure Storage Queues.
trans-unit.target: Choose one of the following templates: Azure Blob Storage, Azure Table Storage, or Azure Storage Queues.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that .NET Framework 4.5 is selected as the target framework.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that .NET Framework 4.5 is selected as the target framework.

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: Specify a name for your project and create the new Visual Studio solution.
trans-unit.target: Specify a name for your project and create the new Visual Studio solution.

trans-unit.source: You may want to review the source code before running the application.
trans-unit.target: You may want to review the source code before running the application.

trans-unit.source: To review the code, select Solution Explorer on the View menu in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: To review the code, select Solution Explorer on the View menu in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Then, double click the Program.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Then, double click the Program.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Next, run the sample application:
trans-unit.target: Next, run the sample application:

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, select Solution Explorer on the View menu.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, select Solution Explorer on the View menu.

trans-unit.source: Double click the App.config file and comment out the connection string for the Azure SDK Storage Emulator:
trans-unit.target: Double click the App.config file and comment out the connection string for the Azure SDK Storage Emulator:

trans-unit.source: Uncomment the connection string for the Azure Storage Service and provide the storage account name and access key in the App.config file:
trans-unit.target: Uncomment the connection string for the Azure Storage Service and provide the storage account name and access key in the App.config file:

trans-unit.source: To find the storage account name and access key, see <link><linkText>What is a Storage Account</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To find the storage account name and access key, see <link><linkText>What is a Storage Account</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: After you provide the storage account name and access key in the App.config file, on the File menu, click Save All to save all the project files.
trans-unit.target: After you provide the storage account name and access key in the App.config file, on the File menu, click Save All to save all the project files.

trans-unit.source: On the Build menu, click Build Solution.
trans-unit.target: On the Build menu, click Build Solution.

trans-unit.source: On the Debug menu, Press F11 to run the solution step by step or press F5 to run the solution.
trans-unit.target: On the Debug menu, Press F11 to run the solution step by step or press F5 to run the solution.
